Award.AwardTitle: Some questions in total positivity and cluster algebras
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project focuses on cluster algebras and total positivity. Fomin and Zelevinsky have repeatedly encountered in their work a new kind of combinatorics, which they axiomatized as so-called cluster algebras. Cluster algebras have found applications in numerous areas of mathematics in recent years, such as quiver representations, non-commutative geometry, discrete integrable systems, Teichmuller theory and even string theory. In joint work with Sergey Fomin, the PI will explore a model for certain cluster algebras in terms of tensor diagrams. The PI will also study a closely related topic of total positivity in joint work with Thomas Lam. Totally positive parts of algebraic groups are closely related to cluster algebras and Lusztig's canonical bases. The proposed research continues the study of affine total positivity, which is a new and fruitful direction in this area.

The proposed project is rooted in two areas of mathematics: representation theory and combinatorics. Representation theory is an important area that is fundamental for the study of quantum mechanics and particle physics. Cluster algebras provide a new approach to representation theory and related disciplines. The PI's research focuses on cluster algebras that lie just beyond the current frontier of our understanding (the so called infinite mutation type). The notion, closely related to cluster algebras, of total positivity first appeared in the literature at the beginning of previous century. It is a major tool for understanding oscillations in mechanical systems. The PI's work concentrates on extending this theory to the affine (or infinite dimensional) case.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project dealt with cluster algebras and discrete dynamical systems. Cluster algebras is a recent development in mathematics which is surprisingly ubiquitous, being of interest in many areas of mathematics and physics. It became an important tool for example in string theory. 

Cluster algebras are certain dynamical systems, where at each point of time one has a collection of variables. One is allowed to swap any of them for a new value, which depends in a certain specific way on the old. Thus one can keep changing values of variables in arbitrary order, as long as one wants. One of the simplest examples has a variable associated to each diagonal of a specific triangulation of a convex polygon. One then can choose one of the diagonals in the triangulation and substitute it for the unique other diagonal which also gives a triangulation when coupled with other (unchanged) diagonals. The value of the new variable is computed using ancient Ptolemy relation.

Two of the main achievements of the project are: 1) developing use of tensor diagrams to model cluster algebras 2) generalizing cluster algebras to more general objects called Laurent phenomenon algebras. 

Both of those developments are likely to open new pages in the theory. Laurent phenomenon algebras for example can be naturally associated with certain simple kinds of electrical networks, giving a new insight into what one would think is a very old and well-studied theory. 

The project provided opportunity for professional training of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdocs. Several of those trained belong to underrepresented minorities.
